div.p: WIVES AS THEY WERE, AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE:
PERFORMED AT THE LONDON AND DUBLIN THEATRES WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE—AND AT GREENWICH-STREET, N. YORK.

p.hi: FIRST AMERICAN—FROM THE THIRD LONDON EDITION.

div.p: NEW-YORK: PRINTED BY R. WILSON, 149, PEARL-STREET.

div.head: PROLOGUE—By a FRIEND, Spoken by Mr. WADDY.

lg.l: I COME not to announce a baſhful Maid

l.hi: Who ne'er has try'd the drama's doubtful trade,
Who ſees with flutt'ring hope the curtain riſe,
And ſcans with timid glance your critic eyes;
My client is a more experienc'd dame,
Tho' not a Veteran, not unknown to Fame,
Who thinks your favours are an honeſt boaſt,
Yet fears to forfeit what ſhe values moſt;
Who has, ſhe truſts, ſome character to loſe,
E'n tho' the woman did not aid the Muſe;
Who courts with modeſt aim the public ſmile,
That ſtamp of merit, and that meed of toil.

lg.l: At Athens once (our author has been told)

l.hi: The Comic Muſe, irregularly bold,
With living calumny profan'd her ſlage,
And forg'd the frailties of the faultleſs ſage.
Such daring ribaldry you need not fear,
We have no Socrates to libel here.
Ours are the follies of an humbler flight,
Offspring of manners, volatile and light;
Our gen'ral ſatire keeps more knaves in awe,
Our court of conſcience comes in aid of law.
Here ſcourg'd by wit, and pilloried by fun,

lg.l: Ten thouſand coxcombs bluſh inſtead of one▪

l.hi: If ſcenes like theſe coul • make the guilty ſhrink,
Could teach unfeeling Folly how to think,
Check Affectation's voluble career,
And from cold Faſhion force the ſtruggling tear,
Our 〈◊〉 w ••• d your loudeſt praiſe forego,
Content to feel within "what paſſes ſhow."
" But ſince" (ſhe ſays) "ſuch hopes cannot be mine,
" Such bold pre • enſions I muſt needs r • ſign,
" Tell theſe great judges of dramatic laws,
" Their reformation were my beſt applauſe;
" Yet if the heart my proud appeal withſtands,
" I aſk the h • mbler ſu •• rage of their hands."

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
COVENT-GARDEN.
DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
GREENWICH-STREET.
WIVES AS THEY WERE, AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE.
ACT I.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
div.stage: Enter Sir William Dorrillon, followed by Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: WHY blame me?—Why blame me?—My ſiſter had the ſole management of your daughter by your own authority, from the age of ſix years, till within eight months of the preſent time, when, in conſequence of my ſiſter's death, ſhe was transferred to my protection.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your ſiſter, Mr. Norberry, was a prudent good woman—ſhe never could inſtruct her in all this vice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: —Depend upon it, my dear friend, that Miſs Dorrillon, your daughter, came to my houſe juſt the ſame heedleſs woman of faſhion you now ſee her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm. (impatiently.)
sp.p: Very well—'Tis very well—But when I think on my diſappointment—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: There is nothing which may not be repaired, Maria, with you for a guide—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Me! She turns me into ridicule—laughs at me! This morning, as ſhe was enumerating ſome of her frivolous expences, ſhe obſerved me lift up my hands and ſigh; on which ſhe named • ifty other extravagances ſhe had no occaſion to mention, merely to enjoy the pang which every folly of her's ſends to my heart.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p:
But do not charge this conduct of your daughter to the want of filial lov •• —did ſhe know you were Sir
William Dorrillon, did ſhe know you were her father, every word you uttered, every look you glanced, would be received with gentleneſs and ſubmiſſion:—but your preſent rebukes from Mr. Mandred (as you are called) from a perfect ſtranger, as ſhe ſuppoſes, ſhe conſiders as an impertinence which ſhe has a right to reſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I wiſh I had continued abroad. And yet, the hope of beholding her, and of beſtowing upon her the riches I acquired, was my ſole ſupport through all the toils by which I gained them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And, conſidering her preſent courſe of life, your riches could not come more opportunely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: She ſhall never have a farthing of them. Do you think I have encountered the perils of almoſt every climate, to ſquander my hard-earned fortune upon the paltry vicious pleaſures in which ſhe delights? No—I have been now in your houſe exactly a month—I will ſtay but one day longer—and then, without telling her who I am, I will leave the kingdom and her for ever—Nor ſhall ſhe know that this inſignificant merchant whom ſhe deſpiſes, was her father, till he is gone, never to be recalled.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: You are offended with ſome juſtice; but, as I have often told you, your exceſſive delicacy and reſpect for the conduct of the other ſex, degenerate into rigour.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: True—for what I ſee ſo near perfection as woman, I want to ſee perfect. WE, Mr. Norberry, can never be perfect; but ſurely women, women, might eaſily be made angels!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And if they were, we ſhould ſoon be glad to make them into women again.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (inattentive to Mr. Nor.)—She ſets the example. She gives the faſhion!—and now your whole houſe, and all your viſitors, in imitation of her, treat me with levity, or with contempt.—But I'll go away to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Can you deſert your child in the moment ſhe moſt wants your protection? That exquiſite beauty juſt now mature—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: There's my difficulty!—There's my ſtruggle!—If ſhe were not ſo like her mother, I could leave her without a pang—caſt her off, and think no more of her—But that ſhape! that face! thoſe ſpeaking looks! Yet, how reverſed!—Where is the diffidence, the humility—where is the ſimplicity of my beloved wife? Bu • ied in her grave.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And, in all this great town, you may never ſee even its apparition.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I rejoice, however, at the ſtratagem by which I have gained a knowledge of her heart: deprived of the means of ſearching it in her early years, had I at preſent come as her father, ſhe might have deceived me with counterfeit manners, till time diſcloſed the impoſition.—Now at leaſt, I am not impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lord Priory.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Lord Priory!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: An old acquaintance of mine, though we ſeldom meet. He has ſome ſingularities; and yet, perhaps—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: My dear Lord, I am glad to ſee you. Mr. Mandred (introducing Sir William). My Lord, I hope I ſee you in perfect health.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Yes: but in very ill humour. I came to London early this morning with my family for the winter, and found my houſe, after going through only a ſlight repair, ſo damp, that I dare not ſleep in it: and ſo I am now ſending and going all over the town to ſeek for lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Then ſeek no farther, but take up your lodgings here.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: To be plain with you, I called in hopes you would aſk me; for I am ſo delicately ſcrupulous in reſpect to lady Priory that I could not bear the thought of taking her to an hotel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Then pray return home, and bring her hither immediately, with all your luggage.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I am moſt extremely obliged to you (very fervently); for into no one houſe belonging to any of my acquaintance would I take my wife, ſo ſoon as into yours. I have now been married eleven years, and during all that time I have made it a rule never to go on a viſit▪ ſo as to domeſticate, in the houſe of a married man.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: May I enquire the reaſon of that?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: It is becauſe I am married myſelf; and having always treated my wife according to the ancient mode of treating wives, I would rather ſhe ſhould never be an eyewitneſs to the modern houſehold management

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: The ancients, I believe, were very affectionate 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: And they had reaſon to be ſo; for their wives obeyed them. The ancients ſeldom gave them the liberty to do wrong: but modern wives do as they like.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And don't you ſuffer lady Priory to do as ſhe likes?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Yes, when it is what I like too. But never, never elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Does not this draw on you the character of an unkind huſband?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: That I am proud of Did you never obſerve, that ſeldom a breach of ſidelity in a wi •• is expoſed, where the unfortunate huſband is not ſaid to be "he beſt creature in the world? Poor man, ſo good-natured?—Doatingly fond of his wife!—indulged her in every thing!—How cruel in her to ſerve him ſo!" Now, if I am ſerved ſo, it ſhall not be for my good-nature.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But I hope you equally diſapprove of every ſeverity.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory (rapidly)
sp.p: What do you mean by ſeverity?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: You know you uſed to be rather violent in your temper.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: So I am ſtill—apt to be haſty and paſſionate—but that is rather of advantage to me as a huſband—it cauſes me to be obeyed without heſitation—no liberty for contention, tears or repining. I inſure conjugal ſunſhine; by now and then introducing a ſtorm; while ſome huſbands never ſee any thing but a cloudy ſky, and all for want of a little domeſtic thunder to clear away the vapours.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I have long conceived indulgence to be the bane of female happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: And ſo it is.—I know ſeveral women of faſhion, who will viſit ſix places of different amuſement on the ſame night, have company at home beſides, and yet, for want of ſomething more, they'll be out of ſpirits; my wife never goes to a public place, has ſcarce ever company at home, and yet is always in ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Never viſits operas, or balls, or routs?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: How ſhould ſhe? She goes to b • d every night exactly at ten.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: In the name of wonder, how have you been able to bring her to that?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: By making her riſe every morning at five.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And ſo ſhe becomes tired before night.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Tired to death. Or, if I ſee her eyes completely open at bed-time, and ſhe aſks me to play one game more at picquet, the next morning I jog her elbow at half after four.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe ſhe does not reply to the ſignal?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Then I turn the key of the door when I leave the chamber; and there I • ind her when I come home in the evening.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And without her having ſeen a creature all day?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: That is in my favour; for not having ſeen a ſingle ſoul, ſhe is rejoiced even to ſee me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And will ſhe ſpeak to you after ſuch uſage?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: If you only conſidered how much a woman longs to ſpeak after being kept a whole day ſilent, you would not aſk that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Well, this is the moſt ſurpriſing method!

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Not at all. In ancient days when manners were ſimple and pure, did not wives wait at the table of their huſbands? and did not angels witneſs the ſubordination? I have taught Lady Priory to practiſe the ſame humble docile obedience—to pay reſpect to her huſband in every ſhape and every form—no careleſs inattention to me—no ſmiling politeneſs to others in preference to me—no putting me up in a corner—in all aſſemblies, ſhe conſiders her huſband as the firſt perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I am impatient to ſee her.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: But don't expect a fine lady with high feathers, and the et caetera of an Eaſtern concubine; you will ſee a modeſt plain Engliſhwoman with a cap on her head▪ a handkerchief on her neck, and a gown of her own manufacture.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My friend Norberry, what a contraſt muſt there be between Lady Priory and the ladies in this houſe!

sp.speaker: Lord Priory (ſtarting)
sp.p: Have you ladies in this houſe!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed; they are both ſingle, and can give Lady Priory no ideas concerning the marriage ſtate.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that? Some ſingle women are more informed than their friends wiſh them to be.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: For theſe ladies, notwithſtanding a few (what you would call) exceſſes, I will anſwer.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Well, then, I and my wife will be with you about nine in the evening; you know we go to bed at ten.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But remember you bring your own ſervants to wait on you at five in the morning.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I ſhall bring but one—my old ſervant Oliver, who knows all my cuſtoms ſo well, that I never go any where without him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And is that old ſervant your valet ſtill?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: No, he is now a kind of gentleman in waiting. I have had no employment for a valet ſince I married:—my wife, for want of diſſipation, has not only time to attend upon herſelf, but upon me. Do you think I could ſuffer a clumſy man to tie on my neckcloth or comb out my hair, when the ſoft, delicate, and tender hands of my wife are at my command?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: After this amiable deſcription of a woman, how can I endure to ſee her, whom reaſon bids me deteſt; but whom nature ſtill—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes; and her companion in folly along with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: There's another woman! that Lady Mary Raffle! How can you ſuffer ſuch people in your houſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: She is only on a viſit for a few months—ſhe comes every winter, as her family and mine have long been intimately connected.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Let us go. I can't bear the ſight of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Stay, and for once behave with politeneſs and good humour to your daughter—do—and I dare venture my life, ſhe will neither inſult nor treat you with diſreſpect. You know you always begin firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Have not I a right to begin firſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: But that is a right of which ſhe is ignorant.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And deſerves to be ſo, and ever ſhall be ſo, I ſtay and treat her with politeneſs and good humour? No—rather let her kneel and implore my pardon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Suffer me to reveal who you are, and ſo ſhe will.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: If you expoſe me only by one inſinuation to her knowledge, our friendſhip is that moment at an end.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor. (Firmly).
sp.p: I have already given you my promiſe on that ſubject; and you may rely upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I thank you—Let us go, I believe you—and I thank you.

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary Raffle and Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.stage: (Stealing on as Mr. Norberry and Sir William leave the ſtage).
sp.p: They are gone. Thank heaven they are gone out of this room, for I expect a dozen viſitors; and Mr. Norberry looks ſo gloomy upon me, he puts me out of ſpirits; while that Mr. Mandred's peeviſhneſs is not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Be ſatisfied; for you were tolerably ſevere upon him this morning in your turn.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why, I am vext—an • d I don't like to be found fault with in my beſt humour, much leſs when I have ſo many things to teaſe me.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I have now loſt all my money, and all my jewels at play; it is almoſt two years ſince I have received a ſingle remittance from my father; and Mr. Norberry refuſes to advance me a ſhilling more. What I ſhall do to diſcharge a debt which muſt be paid either to-day or to-morrow heaven knows! Dear Lady Mary, you could not lend me a ſmall ſum, could you?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Who? I! [with ſurpriſe]—My dear creature, it was the very thing I was going to aſk of you: for when you have money, I know no one ſo willing to diſperſe it among her friends.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Am not I!—I proteſt I love to part with my money; for I know with what pleaſure I receive it myſelf, and I like to ſee that joy ſparkle in another's eye, which has ſo often brightened my own. But laſt night ruined me—I muſt have money ſomewhere.— • s you can't aſſiſt me, I muſt aſk Mr. Norberry for his carriage, and immediately go in ſearch of ſome friend that can lend me four, or five, or ſix, or ſeven hundred pounds. But the worſt is, I have loſt my credit—Is not that dreadful?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know what it is.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Why don't you marry, and throw all your misfortunes upon your huſband?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why don't you marry? For you have as many to throw as I have.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: But not ſo many lovers who would be willing to receive the load. I have no Sir George Evelyn with ten thouſand pounds a year—no Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: If you have not now, you once had: for I am ſure Bronzely once paid his addreſſes to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: And you have the vanity to ſuppoſe you took him from me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Silence.—Reſerve your anger to de • end, and not to attack me. We ſhould be allies by the common ties of poverty: and 'tis time to arm; for here's the enemy.

div.stage: Enter Sir William and Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: They are here ſtill.
sp.stage: (Aſide to Mr. Norberry, and offering to go back.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: (Preventing him.) No, no.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I have been waiting here, Mr. Norberry, to aſk a favour of you.
Will you be ſo kind as to lend me your carriage for a couple of hours?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor. Mr. Mandred
sp.p: has juſt aſked me for it to take him into the city.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Mandred will give it up to Miſs Dorrillon, I am ſure; he can defer his buſineſs till to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No Madam▪ ſhe may as well put off hers. I have money to receive, and I can't do it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I have money to pay, and I can't do it.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: If one is going to receive, and the other to pay money, I think the beſt way is for you to go together; and then, what deficiency there is on one ſide, the other may ſupply.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Will you conſent, Mr. Mandred?—Come, do; and I'll be friends with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: "She'll be friends with me!"

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Well. I certainly can aſk a favour of Mr. Mandred better than I can of any perſon in the world.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Why ſo, Maria?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Becauſe, inſtead of pain, I can ſee it gives him pleaſure to refuſe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I never confer a favour, of the moſt trivial kind, where I have no eſteem.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Nor would I receive a favour, of the moſt trivial kind, from one who has not liberality to eſteem me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Come, Miſs Dorrillon, do not grow ſerious: laugh as much as you pleaſe, but ſay nothing that—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: From whom then can you ever receive favours, except from the vain, the idle, and the depraved?—from thoſe whoſe lives are paſſed in begging them of others?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: They are the perſons who know beſt how to beſtow them: for my part, had I not ſometimes felt what it was to want a friend, I might never have had humanity to be the friend of another.

div.stage: Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: And pray, my dear, whoſe friend have you ever been?—
—Not Sir George Evelyn's, I am ſure; and yet he of all others deſerves your friendſhip moſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: But friendſhip will not content him: as ſoon as he thought he had gained that—

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: He aſpired to the ſupreme happineſs of your love.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Now you talk of "ſupreme happineſs," have you provided tickets for the fete on Thurſday?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I have; provided you have obtained Mr. Norberry's leave to go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: That I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Sir, do not force me to go without it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Would you dare?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: "Would I dare," Mr. Mandred!—and what have you to ſay if I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I was only going to ſay, that if you did, and I were Mr. Norberry—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: And if you were Mr. Norberry, and treated me in the manner you now do, depend upon it 〈◊〉 ſhould not think your approbation or diſapprobation, your pleaſure or diſpleaſure, of the ſlighteſt conſequence.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (Greatly agitated.) I dare ſay not—I dare ſay not. Good morning, Sir George—I dare ſay not.—Good morning, Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Slopt a moment.—Maria, you have offended Mr. Mandred.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: He has offended me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I ſhan't offend you long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.stage: (Going to him, and taking him by the arm)
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Mandred: Miſs Dorrillon, make an apology; Mr. Mandred is my friend, and you muſt not treat him with this levity.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: No, no apology.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No, no apology▪ But I'll tell you what I'll do.

—If Mr. Mandred likes, I'll ſhake hands with him—and we'll be good friends for the future. But then, don't find fault with me—I can't bear it. You don't like to be found fault with, yourſelf—You look as croſs as any thing every time I ſay the leaſt word againſt you. Come, ſhake hands; and don't let us ſee one another's failings for the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: There is no future for the trial.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred ſets off again for India to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Indeed! I thought he was come to live in England! I am ſorry you are going.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Why ſorry?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Becauſe we have ſo frequently quarrelled. I am always unhappy when I am going to be parted from a perſon with whom I have diſagreed; I often think I could part with leſs regret from a friend.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Not, I ſuppoſe, if the quarrel is forgiven?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Ah! but Mr. Mandred does not forgive! no! in his looks I can always ſee reſentment—Sometimes indeed I have traced a ſpark of kindneſs, and have gently tried to blow it to a little flame of friendſhip; when, with one haſty puff I have put it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You are right. It is—I believe—extinguiſhed.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: A very ſingular man.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Oh! if he was not rich, there would be no bearing him—indeed he ſeems to have loſt all his friends; for during the month he has been here, I never found he had any one acquaintance out of this houſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
And what is very ſtrange, he has taken an averſion to me.—But it is ſtill more ſtrange, that although I
know he has, yet in my heart I like him. He is moroſe to an inſufferable degree; but then, when by chance he ſpeaks kind, you cannot imagine how it ſoothes me.—He wants compaſſion and all the tender virtues; and yet, I frequently think, that if any ſerious misfortune were to be • al me, he would be the firſt perſon to whom I ſhould fly to complain.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Then why don't you • ly and tell him of your misfortune laſt night.

sp.speaker: Sir George
sp.p: What misfortune?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: A loſs at play.—
—I beg your pardon, but it was out before you ſaid huſh.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Ah! Maria, will you ſtill riſk your own and my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Your happineſs and mine, Sir!—I beg you will not place them ſo near to each other.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Mine is ſo firmly fixed on you, it can only exiſt in yours.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Then, when ſhe is married to Mr. Bronzely, you will be happy becauſe 〈◊〉 will be ſo?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Bronzely! has he dared?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Have not you dared, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: But I believe Mr. Bronzely is the moſt daring of the two.—
—Take care of him.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Miſs Dorrillon, I will not affront you by ſuppoſing that you mean ſeriouſly to receive the addreſſes of Mr. Bronzely; but I warn you againſt giving others, who know you leſs than I do, occaſion to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I never wiſh to deceive any one—I do admit of Mr. Bronzely's addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why, he is the profeſſed lover of your friend Lady Mary! or granting he denies it, and that I even paſs over the frivolity of the cox • omo, ſtill he is unworthy of you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: He ſays the ſame of you; and half a dozen more ſay exactly the ſame of each other. If you like, I'll diſcard every one of you as unworthy; but if I retain you, I will retain the reſt. Which do you chooſe?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I ſubmit to any thing rather than the total loſs of you—But remember, that your felicity—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
"Felicity! felicity!"—ah! that is a word
not to be found in the vocabulary of my ſenſations!—ſighing.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I believe you, and have always regarded you with a compaſſion that has augmented my love. In your infancy, deprived of the watchful eye and anxious tenderneſs of a mother; the manly caution and authority of a father; miſled by the brilliant vapour of faſhion; ſurrounded by enemies in the garb of friends—Ah! do you weep? bleſſed, bleſſed be the ſign! Suffer me to dry thoſe tears I have cauſed, and to give you a knowledge of true felicity.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p:
I am very angry with myſelf.—Don't, I beg, tell Mr. Norberry or Mr. Mindred you ſaw me cry—they'll ſuppoſe I have been more indiſcreet (
〈◊〉 her tears) than I really have. For in reality I have nothing—

sp.speaker: Sir George,
sp.p: Do not endeavour to conceal from me, what my tender concern for you has given me the means to become acquainted with. I know you are plunged in difficulties by your father neither ſending nor coming, as you once expected—I know you are ſtill deeper plunged in your fondneſs for play.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Very well, Sir—proceed.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Thus, then—Suffer me to ſend my ſteward to you this morning; he ſhall regulate your accounts, and place them in a ſtate that ſhall protect you from further embarraſſment till your father ſends to you; or protect you from his reproaches, ſhould he arrive.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Sir George, I have liſtened to your detail of vices which I acknowledge, with patience, with humility—but your ſuſpicion of thoſe which I have not, I treat with pride, with indignation.

sp.speaker: Sir George,
sp.p: How! ſuſpicion!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: What part of my conduct, Sir, has made you dare to ſuppoſe I would extricate myſelf from the difficulties that ſurround me, by the influence I hold over the weakneſs of a lover?

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I. Another Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
div.stage: Enter two porters from an upper entrance, bringing in trunks; Lord Priory and Mr. Norberry following.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p:
HERE, Stephens, why are you out of the
way? Shew the men with theſe boxes into the dreſſing-room appointed for my Lord Priory.
sp.stage: (A ſervant enters on the oppoſite ſide, and the porters follow him off at a lower entrance on that ſide)

div.stage: Enter Sir William Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope I ſee you well this evening.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—and you find I have literally accepted Mr. Norberry's invitation, and am come to him with my luggage.

div.stage: Enter Oliver, with a ſmall box in each hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory,
sp.p: Follow thoſe men with the tr • nks, Oliver.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Oliver, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Oliver,
sp.p: Pretty well—tolerably well! I thank you, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory (to her)
sp.p: Mr. Norberry, our worthy hoſt; and Mr. Mandred

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: I hope your ladyſhip will find my houſe ſo little inconvenient to you, as to induce you to make no very ſhort viſit.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I have no doubt, Sir, but I ſhall find, from your friendſhip, every comfort in this houſe which it is poſſible for me to enjoy out of my own.

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary Raffle and Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Lady Priory—Lady Mary Raffle—Miſs Dorrillon—Lord Priory.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Permit me, Lady Priory, to take you to the next room: we are going to have tea immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I have drank tea, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Already! It is only nine o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Then it is near my hour of going to bed.
sp.stage: (Lord Priory, Sir William, and Mr. Norberry, retire to the back of the ſtage, and talk apart.)

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Go to bed already! in the name of wonder, what time did you riſe this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Why, I do think it was almoſt ſix o'clock.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary
sp.p: And were you up at ſix this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: At ſix in the month of January!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: It is not light till eight: and what good, now could you poſſibly be doing for two hours by candle-light?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Pray, Lady Mary, at what time did you go to bed?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: About three this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: And what good could you poſſibly be doing for eleven hours by candle-light?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Good! It's as much as can be expected from a woman of faſhion▪ if ſhe does no harm.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: But I ſhould fear you would do a great deal of harm to your health, your ſpirits, and the tranquillity of your mind.
sp.stage: [Mr. Norberry goes off—Lord Priory and Sir William come forward.]

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord Priory, I realy find all the accounts I have heard of your education for a wife to be actually true!—and I can't help laughing to think, if you and I chanced to have married together, what a different creature you moſt likely would have made of me, to what I am at preſent!

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Yes; and what a different creature you moſt likely would have made of me, to what I am at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Lady Priory I am not accuſtomed to pay compliments, or to ſpeak my approbation, even when praiſe is a juſt tribute; but your virtues compel me to an eulogium.—That wiſe ſubmiſſion to a huſband who loves you, that cheerful ſmile ſo expreſſive of content, and that plain dreſs which indicates the elegance as well as the ſimplicity, of your mind, are all ſymbols of a heart ſo unlike to thoſe which the preſent faſhion of the day has miſled—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why look ſo ſtedfaſtly on me, Mr. Mandred? Do you pretend to ſee my heart?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Have you any?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Yes; and one large enough to hold—even my enemy.

div.stage: Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Shew him into the other room.
Come, Lady Priory we muſt introduce you to Mr. Bronzely: he is one of the moſt faſhionable, agreeable, pleaſant, whimſical unthinking, and ſpirited creatures in all the world: you'll be charmed—

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I dare • a • it's near ten o'clock. I am afraid I ſhan't be able to keep awake.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You muſt—We are going to have a little concert—'Twill be impoſſible to ſleep.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Upon my word, my Lord, your plan of management has made your wife unfit for company.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: So much more fit to be a wife.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: She is abſolutely fatigued with hard labour—for ſhame!—How does houſehold drudgery become her hand?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Much better than cards and dice do yours.
sp.stage: [Exit Lady Mary followed by Lord Prior,—Sir William is left on the ſtage alone.]

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: She "has a heart large enough to receive her enemy."—And by that enemy ſhe menas her father.
sp.stage: [He ſits down, and ſhew • marks of inquietude. Enter Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Mr. Mandred—I hope I don't interrupt you—I only wiſhed to ſpeak to Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: She is juſt gone into the next room,

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: To the concert?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Are not you invited?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Yes; but before I go in, I wiſh to know who are the company.—Can you tell whether—a Mr. Bronzely is there?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I know he is.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with him?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I have met him here frequently.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: And are you certain he is here at preſent?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I have reaſon to be certain.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Any particular reaſon?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your miſtreſs, when his name was announced, went out to him, exclaiming "he was the moſt charming and accompliſhed man in the world."

sp.speaker: Sir George
sp.p: She loves him, Sir—I have reaſon to believe—to know ſhe loves him. Thus ſhe gives up my happineſs and her own, to gratify the vanity of a man who has no real regard for her; but whoſe predominant paſſion is to enjoy the villanous name of a general ſeducer.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Why do you ſuffer it?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Hu • h! Don't repeat what I have ſaid, or I loſe her for ever. I am at preſent under her reſentment; and have juſt ſent into the next room, to aſk, if ſhe were there, to ſpeak with her.

div.stage: Enter Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dorrillon.
sp.p: And is it poſſible I was ſent for by you?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Don't be offended, that I ſhould be uneaſy and 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I can't forgive you, Sir, 'ti • impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: You pardon thoſe, 〈◊〉 a, who offend you more.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: But an ungrateful mind always prefers the unworthy.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Mandred, are you there? (playfully And have you undertaken to be ſir George's counſel? If you have, I believe he muſt loſe his cauſe. To fit you for the tender taſk of advocate in love,—have you ever been admitted an honourable member of that court? Have you, with all that ſolemn wiſdom of which you are maſter, ſtudied Ovid, as our great laywers ſtudy Blackſtone? If you have—ſhew cauſe—why plaintiff has a right to defendant's heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: A man of fortune, of family, and of character, ought at leaſt to be treated with reſpect, and with honour.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You mean to ſay, That A is beloved by B, why ſhould not A be conſtrained to return B's love? Counſellor for defendant—Becauſe, moreover, and beſides B who has a claim on defendant's heart, there are alſo C, D, E, F, and G; all of whom put in their ſeparate claims—and what, in this caſe, can poor A do? She is willing to part and divide her love, ſhare and ſhare alike; But B will have all or none: ſo poor A muſt remain A by herſelf A

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Do you think I would accept of a ſhare of your heart!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Do you think I could afford to give it you all? "Beſides," ſays defendant's counſellor, I will prove that plaintiff B has no heart to give defendant in return—he has, indeed, a pulſation on the left ſide; but as it never beat with any thing but ſuſpicion and jealouſy; in the laws of love, it is not termed, admitted, or conſidered a heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Geoege.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: To the muſic-room, to be ſure: and if you follow me, it ſhall be to ſee me treat every perſon there better than yourſelf—and Mr. Bronzely, whom you hate to ſee me treat him beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I muſt follow you, though to death.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
Fool,—and yet am not I near • y as weak as he is? Elſe why do 〈◊〉
• inger in this houſe? Why feed my hopes with ſome propitious moment to waken her to repentance? Why 〈◊〉 anxiouſly wiſh to ward off ſome dreadful fate?—If ſhe would marry ſir George, now—if ſhe would give me
only one proof of diſcretion, I think I would endeavour to take her to my heart.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Bronzely, in great haſte.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: My dear ſir, will you do me the greateſt favour in the world?—You muſt do it in an inſtant too. Do, my dear ſir, aſk no queſtions; but lend me your coat for a ſingle moment, and take mine—only for a moment—I cannot explain reaſons now, my impatience is ſo great;—but, the inſtant you have complied, I will inform you of the whole ſecret; and you will for ever rejoice that you granted my requeſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (aſide, with great ſcorn.) And this very contemptible fellow is the favoured lover of my daughter!—I'll—(after a ſtruggle)—yes—I'll make myſelf maſter of his ſecret—it may poſſibly concern her—my child—my child's ſafety may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Mandred, no time is to be loſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: This is rather a ſtrange requeſt, Mr. Bronzely. However, your fervency convinces me you muſt have ſome very forcible reaſon.—There's my coat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Thank you, dear Sir, a thouſand times.—This goodneſs I ſhall forever remember—This binds me to you forever!—(putting it on.) Thank you, Sir, a thouſand times!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (after putting on the other coat.) And now, Sir, explain the cauſe of this metamorphoſis—let me have the ſatisfaction to know what advantage will accrue from it; and in what I have to rejoice.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Will you promiſe me not to reveal the ſecret, if I truſt you with it?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Would you add conditions after the bargain is made? I muſt know your ſecret inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Then I will diſcloſe it to you voluntarily; and rely on your honour to keep it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (attentively.) Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Hark! I thought I heard ſomebody coming!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I inſiſt upon the information.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p:
Well, then, Sir—well—you ſhall—you ſhall.—Then, Sir—in the ſmall gallery, which ſeparates the muſic-room from the reſt of theſe apartments—in that little
gallery, the lamp, unfortunately, is juſt gone out.—I was (as unfortunately) coming along, when the whiſking of a woman's gown made me give a ſudden ſtart!—I found a perſon was in the gallery with me, and in the dark.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well▪ Sir!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And ſo, confidently aſſuring myſelf, that it was Miſs Dorrillon's waiting-maid, or Lady Mary's waiting-maid, I moſt unluckily claſped my arms around her, and took one kiſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Only one?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: There might be half a dozen! I won't pretend to ſwear to one. We'll ſay half a dozen, before I knew who ſhe was. My rapidity would not let her breathe at firſt, and ſhe was fairly ſpeechleſs. But the moment ſhe recovered her breath, ſhe cry'd, "Villain! whoever you are, you will repent this;"—and I found it was the voice of a lady to whom I had juſt been introduced in the concert-room, one Lady Priory—It ſeems ſhe was ſtealing to bed at the time we unhappily met.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: But what has this to do with your coat?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: A great deal, ſir—you will find a great deal.—As I perceived ſhe did not know me, I carefully held my tongue—but ſhe, with her prudiſh notions, called "Help!" and "Murder!" On which, I flew to the door, to get away before the lights could be brought—ſhe flew after me; and, as I went out, exclaimed—Don't hope to conceal yourſelf: I ſhall know you among the whole concert-room; for I carry ſciſſors hanging at my ſide, and I have cut a piece off your coat.—[Sir William looks haſtily at his coat—on which Bronzely holds up the part cut▪ ]—and ſure enough, ſo ſhe had!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (in anger.) And what, ſir, am I to have the diſgrace—

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Either you or I muſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And do you dare—

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Conſider, my dear ſir, how much leſs the • ault is, if perpetrated by you, than by me! This is the firſt offence of the kind which, I dare ſay, you have committed this many a year; and it will be overlooked in you. But I have been ſuſpected of two or three things of the ſame ſort within a very ſhort time; and I ſhould never be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Nor ought you to be forgiven—it would be ſcandalous in me to connive—

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p:
But would it not be more ſcandalous to reveal
the ſecret of a perſon who confided in you?—who flew to you in diſtreſs, as his friend, the partner of his cares?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Your impertinence to me, but more your offence to a woman of virtue, deſerves puniſhment. Yet I think the puniſhment of death, in the way that a man of my Lord Priory's temper might inflict it, much too honourable for your deſerts; ſo I ſave your life for ſome leſs creditable end. I lend you my coat, to diſgrace you by exiſtence; and will go to my chamber, and put on another m • ſelf. (Paſſes Bronzel, in order to retire to his chamber.)

div.stage: Enter Lord Priory, who meets him. Sir Wm. ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: [going up to Lord Priory.) Ah, my Lord! is the concert over? charming muſic! that ſolo was divine.

sp.speaker: [Sir Wm.
sp.p: ſteals to a chair, and ſits down to hide his coat.]

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: [after looking inquiſitively at Bronzely's dreſs.] It is time the concert ſhould be over—it had been better it had never begun; for there have been ſome very improper perſons admitted. [In great anger.]

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: [affecting ſurpriſe.] Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (trembling with rage) I am at a loſs how to act. (Draws a chair with violence, and places himſelf down by Sir William—Sir William appears diſconcerted and uneaſy.) But if I could find the man to whom this piece of cloth belongs—

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: What! this ſmall piece of woolen cloth?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Yes, then I ſhould know how to act. In the mean time, Mr Mandred, as I know you are a great admirer of my wife [Sir William ſtarts], and a grave prudent man of honour, I come to aſk your advice, how I am the moſt likely to find out the villain who has dared to inſult her; for a groſs inſult ſhe has received from one of Mr. Norberry's viſitors, wearing a coat of which this is a part.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: The villain, no doubt, ſtole out of the houſe immediately.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I ordered the ſtreet door to be guarded that inſtant—and you, Mr. Bronzely, are now the laſt man whoſe habit I have examined.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And you ſee I am perfectly whole. [turning round.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I do ſee—I do ſee. [Sir William moves about on his chair, and appears greatly embarraſſed. Lord Priory ſtarts up in a violent paſſion—Sir William ſtarts up with him.]

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I'll find him out if he is on earth—I'll find him out if—My paſſion carries me away—I have not coolneſs to detect him myſelf—I'll employ another—I'll ſend Oliver in ſearch. Oliver! [calling] Oliver! here, Oliver! Why don't you anſwer when you are called, you ſtupid, dull, idle, forgetful, blundering, careleſs, ſelf-ſufficient—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (riſing with great dignity.) And now, Mr. Bronzely, how do you think you are to repay me, for having fe • t one tranſitory moment of ſhame? Underſtand, Sir, that ſhame is one of the misfortunes to which I have never—

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: (Aſide to Sir Wm) Sit down, ſit down—ſit down—hold your tongue, and ſit down.
sp.stage: [Sir William reluctantly retires to his chair.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Well, I do moſt cordially rejoice, when peeviſh, ſuſpicious, and cenſorious people, meet with humiliation! I could die with laughing at the incident which has put both my Lord and my Lady Priory into the greateſt terror, grief, and rage.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (riſing.) I am out of all patience. The malicious depravity of perſons in a certain ſphere of life is not to be borne. [With firmneſs and ſolemnity.] Lady Mary—Mr. Bronzely—

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: (in a half whiſper to him.) Go away—don't expoſe yourſelf—ſteal out of the room—take my advice, and go to bed—hide yourſelf. So great is my reſpect for you, I would not have you detected for the world.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I am going to retire, ſir. I would not throw my friend's houſe into confuſion and broils; therefore I am as well pleaſed not to be detected as you can be. (Goes to the door, then turns.) But before I quit the room, I am irreſiſtibly impelled to ſay—Mr. Bronzely! Lady Mary! while you continue to ridicule all that is virtuous, eſtimable, dignified, your vices moſt aſſuredly will plunge you into that very diſgrace—

div.stage: (Enter Oliver, and places the piece of cloth againſt Sir William's coat.)

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: 'Tis as exact a match as ever was—it fits to a thread. Ha, ha, ha!—Ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Did not I entreat you to go to-bed!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Oh! this is the higheſt gratification I ever knew. My Lord! my Lord! (calling.)

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh!—hold, for heaven's ſake.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: But mercy and goodneſs defend us! who would have thought of this grave gentleman? Ha, ha, ha!—I can tell you what, ſir; my Lord will be in a terrible paſſion with you. This houſe won't ho • d you both; and I am ſure I hate to make miſchief.—Mum—I'll ſay nothing about it. (clapping Sir William on the ſhoulder.) And ſo make yourſelf eaſ • .

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: (on the other ſide of Sir William.) Yes, make yourſelf eaſy.

sp.speaker: Oliver▪
sp.p: A good ſervant ſhould ſometimes be a peacemaker—for my part, I have faults of my own, and ſo, I dare ſay, has that gentleman—and ſo, I dare ſay, has that gentlewoman. But of all the birds in the wood, how came you to make up to my Lady? Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: No jeſts—no jeſts. Mr. Mandred is my beſt friend.—and he is not ſo much to b • ame as you think, for—Good night, my dear ſir. Heaven bleſs you. I thank you a thouſand times. Good night. (Shaking hands with Sir William, and leading him towards the door)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (with ſteady compoſure) Good night. Good night. Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Why, he never ſo much as once ſaid he was obliged to me.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: I am ſure, if you do not diſcover this to your maſter, I will.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Oh! as that old gentleman had not manners to ſay "thank you for your kindneſs," I'll go tell my Lord directly.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: (running after him.) No, no, no—ſtop Oliver. He is gone!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: What makes you thus anxious and concerned, Bronzely? Now, I wiſh I may ſuffer death, if, ti • l I came into this room, I did not think you were the offender.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: 〈◊◊〉 indeed!—No, if I could have been tempted to offend any woman in this houſe in a ſimilar manner, it could have been none but you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p:
No, Bronzely, no; I have been too partial
to you, to have any remaining claims—Hark! don't I hear Lord Priory's voice in a dreadful rage?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Then Oliver has accuſed him▪ What ſhall I do to prevent miſchief? Dear Lady Mary, as it is not proper for me to ſtay here any • onger uninvited, do you run and try to pacify my Lord Priory. Te •• him Mandred does not ſleep here to-night; and in the morning you are ſure he will make an apology.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: I will do as you deſire—but I know Mr. Mandred ſo well, that I am ſure he will not.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Then I will for him. Early in the morning, I'll wait on Lady Priory, and beg pardon in his name without his knowing it. Yes, I have got poor Mandred into a difficulty, and it is my duty to get him out of it. And then, I ſhall not only ſerve him, but have one interview more with that heavenly woman.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Bronzely, followed by a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: (looking at his watch.) I am early, I know—but Lady Priory is the only perſon I wiſh to ſee. Is my Lord with her?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: No, ſir, Lord Priory ſat up very late, and is in bed yet.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Acquaint Lady Priory a perſon who comes on urgent buſineſs, begs to ſpeak with her. If ſhe aſks my name, you know it. (Exit Servant.) Pray heaven ſhe may bleſs me with her ſight: Never was ſo enchanted b • a woman in my life—and never was played ſuch a trick in my life▪ I am half inflamed b • love, and half by ſpite, once more to attempt her.

div.stage: Enter Lady Priory—he bows moſt reſpectfully, ſhe cur • ſ • es.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Lady Priory, I come—I come upon rather an a •• ward, yet a very ſerious buſineſs: it was my misfortune to be among that company yeſterday evening, where an unworthy member of it had the inſolence to offer an aff •• nt to your reſplendent virtue—

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I have ſome houſehold accounts to arrange, and breakfaſt to make for my Lord as ſoon as he 〈◊〉 his 〈◊〉 ; therefore, if you pleaſe, Sir proceed to the buſineſs • n which you came, without thinking it neceſſary to interrupt it by any compliment to me.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I will be conciſe, Madam.—In a word▪ I wait upon you from Mr. Mandred, with the moſt humble apology for his late conduct, which he acknowledges to have been indecorous and unwarrantable: but he truſts, that in conſequence of the conceſſion which I now make for him, the whole matter wi •• , from this hour, be buried in oblivion.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory
sp.p: [going to the ſide of the ſcene, and ſpeaking.] If my Lord is at leiſure, te • l him here is a gentleman would be glad to ſpeak with him.—To Bronzely. I am ſorry, Sir, you ſhould know ſo little of the rules of our family, as to ſuppoſe that I could give an anſwer upon any ſubject in which my huſband condeſcends to be concerned.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Lady Priory, ſtop. You can at leaſt uſe your power to ſoften Lord Priory's reſentment; and unleſs this apology is accepted, a challenge muſt follow, and poſſibly he may fall.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Poſſibly. [Sighing.]

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You are intereſted for your huſband's life?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Certainly. But I ſet equal value on his reputation.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Hear me one ſentence more—I cannot part from her. Aſide] Oh I have ſomething of ſuch importance to communicate to you—and yet—I know not how!

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Then te •• it to my huſband.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Hem, hem. Aſide]. Oh! Lady Priory, if the inſult of laſt night has given you offence, ſhould you not wiſh to be informed of a plan laid for yet greater violence?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Good heaven!

sp.speaker: Bronzely▪
sp.p: This is neither time nor place to diſcloſe what I wiſh to ſay—nor do I know how to find an opportunity to ſpeak with you alone, free from the poſſibility of intruſion; where I could revea • a ſecret to you, which is connected with your happineſs, with your future peace,

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: You alarm me beyond expreſſion. I am going to my own houſe about twelve o'clock, for a couple of hours—follow me there.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And I ſhall be admitted?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Certain •• —for you have excited my curioſity, and I am all impatience to hear what you have to communicate that ſo much concerns me.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Promiſe then, no perſon but yourſelf ſhall • ver know of it. [She heſitates.] Unleſs you promiſe this, I 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: [after a ſecond heſitation] I do promiſe—I promiſe faithfully.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Your word is ſacred, I rely.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Moſt ſacred.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And you promiſe that no one but yourſelf ſhall know of the appointment we have now made at your houſe, nor of the ſecret which I will then diſcloſe to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I promiſe faithfully that no one but myſelf ſhall ever know of either.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Remember then to be there alone, exactly—

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: At one o'clock.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And that your ſervants have orders to ſhew me to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I am too much intereſted to forget one circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Go now then to Lord Priory with Mandred's apology—and arge his acceptance of it, with all that perſuaſion by which you are formed to govern, while you appear to obey.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I will preſent the apology as I received it from you; but do not imagine I dare give my opinion upon it, unleſs I am deſired.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: But if you are deſired, you will then ſay—

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Exactly what I think.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I'll do a meritorious act this very day. This poor woman lives in ſlavery with her huſband. I'll give her an opportunity to run away from him. When we meet, I'll have a poſt-chaiſe waiting a few doors from her houſe; boldly tell her that I love her; and—(Enter Miſs Dorrillon.)—My dear Miſs Dorrillon, I could not ſleep all night, but am come thus early on purpoſe to complain of your treatment of me during the whole of yeſterday evening. Not one look did you glance towards me—and there I ſat in miſerable ſolitude up in one corner the whole time of the concert.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I proteſt I did not ſee you!—and, ſtranger ſtill! never thought of you.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You then like another better than you do me?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Do you tell him ſo?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You tell him you like me the beſt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p:
Then I will believe what you ſay to him, and
not what you ſay to me.—And though you charge me with inconſtancy, yet I ſwear to you, my beloved Maria, (taking her hand) that no woman, no woman but yourſelf—

div.stage: Enter Sir William, and ſtarts at ſeeing his Daughter in ſuch cloſe converſation with Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Sir William
sp.p: (aſide.) How familiar!—My eyes could not be ſhocked with a ſight half ſo wounding to my heart as this!

sp.speaker: Huſh!
sp.p: you have heard the ſtory; but don't laugh at him now. He is in a deviliſh ill humour, and it will all fall on me. Go away.—It's a very good ſtory, but laugh at him another time.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I don't believe a word of the ſtory; yet, as a received opinion, it is a charming weapon for an enemy, and I long to uſe it.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Not now, not now—becauſe I have ſome buſineſs with him, and 'twill put him out of temper. (He hands her to the door)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm
sp.p: (Looking ſtedfaſtly after her.) Poor girl! Poor girl! I am not yet ſufficiently enraged againſt her, not to compaſſionate her for her choice!—Is this the man who is to be, for life, her companion, her protector?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Well, Mr Mandred, I believe I have ſettled it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Settled what? (anxiouſly)

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: At leaſt I have done all in my power to ſerve you; perhaps you don't know that Mr. Oliver divulged the whole affair. But I have waited on my Lady Priory, and I do believe I have ſettled it with her, to manage it ſo with my Lord, that every thing ſhall be hu • hed up. You may expect a few jeſts among your female acquaintance, and a few epig • a •• s in the news-papers; but I verily believe every thing material is ſafe.—Is there any farther ſatisfaction which you demand from me?

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Not at preſent—a man is eaſily ſatisfied who poſſeſſes both courage and ſtrength to do himſelf right, whenever he feels his wrongs oppreſſive. I have as yet found but little inconvenience from the liberties you have taken with me; and what, juſt at this time, far more engages my attention than revenge, is an application to you for intelligence. Without farther preface, do you pay your addreſſes to the young lady who lives in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Yes I do, Sir—I do.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: You know, I ſuppoſe, which of the two ladies I mean?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Which ever you mean Sir 'its all the ſame; for I pay my addreſſes to them both.

sp.speaker: Sir William
sp.p: [ſtarting.] To them both!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I always do.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: And pray, which of them do you love?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Both, Sir—upon my word, both—I aſſure you, both.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: But you don't intend to marry both?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I don't intend to marry either: and indeed, the woman whom I love beſt in the world, has a huſband already. Do you ſuppoſe I could con • ine my affections to Lady Mary or Miſs Dorrillon, after Lady Priory appeared? do you ſuppoſe I did not know who it was I met laſt night in the dark? wherever I viſit, Mr. Mandred, I always make love to every woman in the houſe: and I aſſure you they all expect it—I aſſure you, Sir, they all expect it.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Have you any further commands for me?

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Yes, one word more—And you really have no regard for this girl who parted from you as I came in?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Oh yes, pardon me—I admire, I adore, I love her to diſtraction: and if I had not been ſo long acquainted with my Lady Mary, nor had ſeen my Lady Priory laſt night, I ſhould certainly call Sir George Evelyn to an account for being ſo perpetually with her.

sp.speaker: Sir William
sp.p: (anxiouſly.) Do you think he loves her?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay, as well as I do.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe likes him?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I think ſhe likes me.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: But, with your method of affection, ſhe may like him too.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: She may, ſhe may—In ſhort, there is no anſwering for what ſhe likes—all whim and flightineſs—acquainted with every body—conquetting with every body—and in debt with every body. Her mind diſtracted between the claims of lovers, and the claims of creditors,—the anger of Mr. Norberry, and the want of intelligence from her father!

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: She is in a hopeful way.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p:
Oh, it would be impoſſible to think of marrying
her in her preſent ſtate—for my part, I can't—and I queſtion whether Sir George would—But if her father come home, and give her the fortune that was once expected, why then I may poſ •• bly marry her myſelf

sp.speaker: Sir William
sp.p: (firmly.) She will never have any fortune—I came from India lately, you know; and you may take my word her father is not coming over, nor will he ever come.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Very ſure.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Then keep it a ſecret—don't tell her ſo—poor thing! it would break her heart. She is do • tingly fond of her father.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Hah! how!—oh no, ſhe can have no remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Not of his perſon, perhaps: but he has conſtantly correſponded with her; ſent her preſents, and affectionate letters—and you know a woman's heart is eaſily impreſſed.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: I never heard her mention her father.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Not to you—but to us who are kind to her, ſhe talks of him continually. She cried bitterly the other day when the laſt ſhip came in, and there was no account of him.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Did ſhe? did ſhe? (eagerly.) Aye, I ſuppoſe ſhe is alarmed leſt he ſhould be dead, and all his fortune loſt.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: No, I believe her affection for him is totally unconnected with any intereſted view • I have watched her upon that head, and I believe ſhe loves her father ſincerely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (wiping a tear from his eye.) I believe it does not matter whom ſhe loves!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: By the bye, ſhe hates you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Yes you may be ſatisfied of that. Yes, ſhe even quarrelled with me the other day for ſpeaking in your favour: you had put her in a paſſion, and ſhe ſaid "no one that lov'd 〈◊〉 , ought to have any •• ſpect for you."

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I am much obliged to her—very much obliged to her. Did ſhe ſay nothing more?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Only "that you were ill-natured, dogmatic, cruel, and inſo ent." Nothing more.—And ſay what ſhe will againſt you, you know you can be even with her.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
Yes, I can be even with her, and I will
〈◊〉 even with her.

div.stage: Enter Lord Priory, and takes Bronzely on one ſide.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I have accepted this man's apology.—I will not call him to a ſerious account; but he ſhall not eſcape every kind of reſentment. I am reſolved to laugh at him; to turn the whole affair into mirth and good humour; and at the ſame time to 〈◊〉 him to the heart. Good morning, Mr. Mandred—how do you do this morning, Mr. Mandred?—Let me go (violently to Bronzely) I muſt joke with him.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: But neither your voice nor your looks agree with your words.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred, I did not intend to be angry—but it would give too reſpectable an air to a baſe action—and ſo I am come to laugh at you. [Enter Lady Mary.] And I am ſure, you, Lady Mary, will join even me, in laughing at this man of gallantry.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Oh, I am abſolutely afraid to come near the Tarquin!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You need not, Lady Mary; for there can be no Tarquin without a Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: However, Mr. Mandred, it is proper I ſhould tell you, I accept the apology you have made: but at the ſame time—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm
sp.p: [haſtily.] What do you mean, my Lord? I have made no apology.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you have—I called and made one for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Made an apology for me! You have juſt gone one ſtep too far then; and I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p:
[Drawing Sir William on one ſide.] I will—I will ſet every thing to rights. It would be baſe in me if I did not; and I will. (Turns to Lord Priory and Lady Mary.) Yes, Mr▪ Mandred, I will retrieve your character at the expence of my own. I am more able to contend with the frenzy of a jealous huſband than you are—(Enter Miſs Dorril on and Sir George Evelyn.)—I am happy to ſee 〈◊〉 —you are juſt come in time to hear me clear the grave, 〈◊〉
••• pectable character of my friend Mr. Mandred, and 〈…〉
• iſe my own.—My Lord, vent all your anger an •
〈…〉 upon me. It was I [pray believe me, I beg you will; •• n't doubt my word], it was I who committed the offence of which my friend, the man I reſpect and reverence, ſtands accuſed—It was I who offended my Lady Priory, and then—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: It can't be—I won't believe you.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: But how generous and noble in him to take it upon himſelf!

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: (to Sir William.) There! what can I do more? You ſee they won't believe me!—Tell me what I can do more? Can I do any thing more?—My feelings are wounded on your account, more than on m • own, and compel me, though reluctantly, to quit the room.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: I am at a • oſs which to admire moſt, the warmth of Mr. Bronzely's friendſhip, or the coldneſs 〈◊〉 Mr. Mandred's gratitude!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary
sp.p: Oh! if it were not for that happy ſteadineſs of feature, he could not preach rectitude of conduct as he does.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (going up to Sir William.) Eloquent admoniſher of • outh!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: (going to him.) Indeed, my rigid monitor, I cannot but expreſs admiration, that, under thoſe auſtere looks, and that ſullen brow, there ſtill ſhou • d • urk—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Have a care—don't proceed—ſtop where you are—dare not you complete a ſentence that is meant to mock me.—I have borne the impertinence of this whole company with patience, with contempt; but dare you to breathe an accent ſuſpicio • s of my conduct, and I wil • inſtantl • teach you how to reſpect me, and to ſhrink with horror from yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: What a paſſion he is in! Compoſe yourſelf, Mr. Mandred.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I proteſt, Mr. Mandred—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Silence. (Raiſing his voice.) Dare not to addreſs yourſelf to me.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Did you ever hear the like?—And I • ow ſhe looks awed by him!

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: How ſtrange, that a man can't command his temper!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred, permit me to ſay, I have ever wiſh 〈◊〉 to treat you with reſpect—nor would 〈◊〉 be raſh in laying that wiſh aſide.—Yet, I muſt now take upon me to aſſure you, that if you think to offend every lady in this houſe with imp ••• ity, you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Sir George, if you mean to frighten me by your threats, I'll laugh at you—but if your warmth is really kindled, and by an attachment to that unworthy object, (pointing to Miſs Dorrillon) I o •• y pity you.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Inſufferable!—(going up to him.)—Inſtantly make an atonement for what you have ſaid, or expect the conſequence!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And pray, Sir George, what atonement does your juſtice demand?

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Retract your words—Acknowledge you were groſsly deceived when you ſaid Miſs Dorrillon was unworthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Retract m • words!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Were they not unjuſt?—Is it a reproach, that, enveloped in the maze of faſhionable life, ſhe has yet preſerved her virtue unſuſpected? That, encumbered with the expences conſequent to her connections, ſhe has proudly diſdained even from me the honourable offer of pecuniary aid? that her fond hope ſtill fixes on the return of an abſent parent, whoſe bleſſing ſhe impatiently expects? and that I ſhou • d have watched her whole conduct with an eye of ſcrutinizing jealouſy, and yet have only beheld that which makes me aſpire, as the ſummit of earthly happineſs, to become her huſband?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Young man, I admire your warmth (with great fervour and affection) There is much compaſſion, and benevolence, and charity, in ſometimes miſtaking the vicious for the virtuous;—and if in the heat of contention I have ſaid a word reflecting on your character, I am ready to avow my error; and before this company to beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p:
That is not enough, Sir—(taking Miſs Dorrillon by the hand, and leading her forwar •
—you muſt aſk this lady's pardon.
sp.stage: (Sir William ſtarts, and turns his face away, ſtrongly impreſſed.)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Aſk her pardon! Though I forgive ſome inſults I will not this.—Aſk her pardon?—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Nay, nay, ſir George, you have no buſineſs with Mr. Mandred's quarrels and mine—Reſerve your heroic courage for ſome nobler purpoſe than a poor woman▪s reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Point out a nobler, and I'll give up this.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: There is none ſo noble? And I wiſh Sir George you would undertake to vindicate mine.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Come, Lady Mary, let us retire, and leave theſe two irritable men to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Come, Maria, let us leave them alone. He'll teach Mr. Mandred to be civil for the future.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: (in great agitation) Dear madam, I would not leave them a one for the world!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Then my Lord, you and I will; they have no offenſive weapons; ſo we may venture to leave them.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: This comes of being too warm in converſation! This comes of being in a paſſion!

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: While there is a female preſent, I have only to ſay—good morning, Mr. Mandred▪

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor
sp.p: (catching hold of him▪) For once I give up my pride to ſoften yours. Come, do not • ook thus determined?—I am ſure Mr▪ Mandred did not mean to offend me; the words he made uſe of fell from his lips by accident.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: They did not—I meant them—I mean them ſtill—and I repeat them

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: (to Sir William) Now how can you be ſo provoking?—Nay, hold Sir George, (he offers to go) you ſhall not go away with that frowning brow. (She draws him gently towards Sir William, then takes Sir William's hand) Nor you, with yours—Come ſhake hands for my ſak • .—Now, as I live, Sir George, Mr. Mandred's hand fee • s warmer and kinder than yours—he tries to draw it back, but he has not the heart. (Sir William ſnatches it away as by compulſion.)—Thou art a ſtrange perſonage!—thou wilt not ſuffer me either to praiſe or to diſpraiſe thee—Come Sir George, make up this difference—for if you were to • ight, and Mr. Mandred was to fall—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Wh •• , "I could better ſpare a better man."

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I ſee you are both ſul • en both obſtinate, and I have but one reſource—Sir George, if you aſpire to my hand, dare not to • ift yours againſt Mr. Mandred He and I profeſs to be enemies; but if may judge of his feelings by my own, we have but paſſing enmities—bear him no ma • ice, nor he me, I dare be ſworn▪ Therefore Sir, li • t but your arm againſt him, or inſult him with another word, and our intercourſe is for ever at an end▪

div.stage: (Sir George and Sir William ſtand for ſome time ſilent)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Why is it in the power of one woman to make two men look ridiculouſly?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I am at a loſs to know, Sir, whether you and I part friends or enemies—However, cal • on me in the way you beſt like, and you will find me ready to meet you either as an enemy, or as a friend, (Exeunt ſeparately.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I. A Hall at Lord Priory's.

stage.hi: Two Servants diſcovered ſ • itting—Another enters.

sp.speaker: Firſt Serv.
sp.p: —Do you hear, Mr. Porter, you are to admit no perſon but Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Second Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely—very well—(a loud rapping)—and there I ſuppoſe he is.

sp.speaker: Firſt Servant,
sp.p: looking through the window. Yes; that I believe is his carriage—(to Third Servant)—Let my ady know.

div.stage: Enter Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You are ſure lady Priory is at home?

sp.speaker: Firſt Serv
sp.p: —Yes, Sir, and gave orders to admit nobody but you.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Has ſhe been ſome time at home?

sp.speaker: Firſt Serv.
sp.p: —Yes, Sir; I dare ſay my lady came from Mr. Norberry's half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Waiting for me half an hour—(aſide)—Shew me her inſtantly.

div.head: SCENE II. An Apartment at Lord Priory's.
div.stage: Enter Bronzely and Lady Priory on oppoſite ſides.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: My dear lady Priory, how kind you are not to have forgotten your promiſe

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: How was it poſſible 〈◊〉 ſhould? I have been ſo anxious for the intelligence • ou have to communicate, that it was pain to wait till the time arrived.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Thus invited, encouraged to ſpeak, I will ſpeak boldly—and I can heaven to witneſs, that what I am going to ſa • —

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: No, ſtay a moment • onger—don't tell me juſt yet—(liſtening towards the ſide of the ſcenes)—for I wiſh him to hear the very beginning.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Who, hear the very beginning?

div.stage: Enter Lord Priory—Bronzely ſtarts.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p:
I have not kept you waiting, 〈◊〉 hope. My lawyer ſtopt me on buſineſs, or I ſhould have been here ſooner. My dear Mr. Bronzely (going up to him)
〈◊〉 thank you a thouſand times for the intereſt you take in my concerns; and I come prepared with proper coo • neſs and compoſure to hear the ſecret with which you are going to entruſt us

sp.speaker: Bronzely▪
sp.p: The ſecret!—yes, Sir—The ſecret which I was going to diſcloſe to my lady Priory—Ha, ha, ha!—But, my lord, I am afraid it is of too frivolous a nature for your attention.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I account nothing frivolous which concerns my wife.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Beſides, ſhe told me it was of the utmoſt importance. Did not you? (angrily.)

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: He ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And ſo it was—it was of importance then—juſt at the very time I was ſpeaking to Lady Priory on the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: You ſaid ſo but this very moment.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Come, come, tell it immediately, whatever it is. Come, let us hear it.—(after waiting ſome time) Why, Sir, you look as if you were aſhamed of it? What can be the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: To be plain, my lord, my ſecret will diſcloſe the folly of a perſon for whom I have a ſincere regard.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: No matter—let every fool look like a fool, and every villain be known for what he is—Tell your ſtory.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: How can you deprive me of the pleaſure you promiſed? You ſaid it would prevent every future care.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Explain, Sir. I begin to feel myſelf not quite ſo compoſed as I expected. You never, perhaps, ſaw me in a paſſion—ſhe has—and if you were once to ſee me really angry—

sp.speaker: Bronzely,
sp.p: Then, my lord, I am apt to be paſſionate too—and I boldly tell you, that what I had to reveal, tho' perfectly proper, was meant for lady Priory alone to hear. I entreated your ladyſhip not to mention to my lord that I had any thing to communicate, and you gave me a ſolemn promiſe you would not.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Upon my honour, during our whole converſation upon that ſubject, you never named my lord Priory's name.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I charged you to keep what I had to tell you a profound ſecret.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Yes; but I thought you underſtood I could have no ſecrets from my huſband.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You promiſed no one ſhould know it but yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: He is myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p:
How, Mr. Bronzely, did you ſuppoſe ſhe and I were two? Perhaps you did, and that we wanted a third. Well, I quite forgive you for your ſi • ly miſtake, and laugh at you, ha, ha, ha, as I did at Mr. Mandred (ſeriouſly—Did you ſuppoſe, ſir, we lived like perſons of faſhion of the modern 〈◊〉 ? Did you imagine that a woman of her
character could have a wiſh, a deſire, even a thought, a ſecret from her huſband?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: It is amazing to find ſo much fidelity the reward of tyranny!

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Sir—I ſpeak with humility—I would not wiſh to give offence—(timidly)—But to the beſt of my obſervation and underſtanding, your ſex, in reſpect to us, are all tyrants. I was born to be the ſlave of ſome of you—I make the choice to obey my huſband.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Bronzely; and I believe it is more her happineſs to be my ſlave, than your friend—to live in fear of me, than in love with you—Lady Priory, leave the room.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Do you ſee—did you obſerve the glow of truth and candour which teſtifies that woman's faith? and do you not bluſh at having attempted it? Call me a tyrant! Where are the ſigns? Oh, if every married man would follow my ſyſtem in the management of his wife, every impertinent lover would look juſt as fooliſh as you!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: This is all boaſting, my lord—you live in continual fear—for (without meaning any offence to lady Priory's honour) you know you dare not truſt her one hour alone with any man under ſixty.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I dare truſt her at any time with a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Bronzely▪
sp.p: That is declaring I am not one—for I am certain you dare not truſt her alone with me.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (in a paſſion) Yes, with fifty ſuch.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: But not with one—and you are right, it might be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (angrily) No, it would not.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: (ſignificantly) Yes, it would.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Have not you had a trial?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: But you were preſent. You conſtantly follow all her ſteps, watch all ſhe ſays and does. But I believe you are right—wives are not to be truſted.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Mine is.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: No, my dear lord Priory, you muſt firſt become gentle, before you can poſitively con • ide in her affection—before you can truſt her in a houſe, or in any place, 〈◊〉 one.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (haſtily) To prove you are miſtaken, I'll inſtantly go back to my friend Norberry's, and leave you here to tell her the ſecret you boaſted. Pay your addreſſes to her, if that is the ſecret—you have my free con • ent.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: My dear friend, I'll accept it.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Ay, I ſee you have hopes of ſupplanting me, by calling me your friend—But can you conceive now that ſhe'll liſten to you?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You have given me leave to try, and can't recal it.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: But depend upon it, you will meet with ſome terrible humiliation.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Either you or I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I ſhall laugh to hear you tumbled down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: You are not to remain on the watch here; you are to return to Mr. Norberry's.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Was that the bargain?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Don't you remember? You ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Well, if that will give you any ſatisfaction—

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: It will give me great ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Heaven forgive me, but your confidence makes me laugh. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And your's makes me laugh.

div.stage: Enter Oliver.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Hah! What brings you here, Oliver? Lady Priory and I are only come home for a few hours.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: I know it, my Lord. I thought nevertheleſs I might be wanted.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: And ſo you are, good Mr. Oliver.
