Your Lord deſires you to conduct me to your Lady in the next room, and acquaint her it is with his permiſſion I am come to conclude the converſation which was juſt now interrupted—Is not that right, my Lord? Are not thoſe words exactly correſponding with your kind promiſe?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I believe they are.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: I am "to take Mr. Bronzely to my Lady, and tell her you ſent him"

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Now this is perfect faſhion; and while I ſtep to Lady Priory, do you go and comfort my intended wife, Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I hate the faſhion—and were I not ſure you would now be received in a very unfaſhionable manner—

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: No rough dealings, I hope?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Oh, you begin to be afraid, do you?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: No—but I have met with an accident or two lately—and I am not ſo well acquainted with ancient uſages as to know in what manner a man of my purſuits would have been treated in former times.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: A man of your purſuits. Mr. Bronzely, is of a very late date; and to be ſhamed out of them by a wife like mine.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Then we ſhall all three be old-faſhioned.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (returning and looking anxiouſly after Bron.) I am paſſionate—I am precipitate—I have no command over my temper.—However, if a man cannot govern himſelf, yet he will never make any very deſpicable figure, as long as he knows how to govern his wife.

div.head: SCENE III. Sir Wm.'s Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.—Several trunks and travelling-boxes.—Sir Wm. diſcovered, packing writings into a port-folio.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And here is the end of my voyage to England!—a voyage, which for years, my mind has dwelt on with delight!—I pictured to myſelf my daughter grown to womanhood, beautiful! and ſo ſhe is.—Accompliſhed! and ſo ſhe is.—Virtuous! and ſo ſhe is.—Am I of a diſcontented nature then, that I am not ſatisfied?—Am I too nice?—Perhaps I am.—Soothing thought!—I will for a moment cheriſh it, and dwell with ſome little gratitude upon her late anxiety for my ſafety. [He walks about in a thoughtful muſing manner.

p.hi: A loud thruſting and rapping is heard at his chamber door.

div.stage: Enter Miſs Dor. haſtily and in affright.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Mandred, I beg your pardon—I did not know this was your apartment. But ſuffer me to lock the door: [ſhe locks it] and conceal me for a moment, for heaven's ſake.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What's the matter? Why have you locked my door?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: [trembling]. I dare not tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I inſiſt upon knowing.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Why then—I am purſued by a—I cannot name the horrid name—

sp.speaker: Nabſon
sp.p: (without.) She went into this room.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: (to Sir Wm.) Go to the door, and ſay I did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Nabſon
sp.p: [without.] Pleaſe to open the door.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Threaten to beat him if he won't go away.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Give me the key, and let me ſee from whom you want to hide.—[commandingly]—Give me the key.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: [collecting firmneſs.] I will not.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: [ſtarting.] "Will not"—"Will not", when I deſire you!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No—ſince you refuſe me protection, I'll protect myſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: But you had better not have made uſe of that expreſſion to me—you had better not. Reca • l it by giving me the key.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: If I do, will you let me conceal myſelf behind that book-caſe, and ſay I am not here?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Utter a falſehood?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I would for you. [A hammering at the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: They are breaking open the door.—Give me the key, I command you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: "Command me!" "command me!" However there it is. [Gives it him.] And now, if you are a gentleman, give me up if you dare!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: "If I am a gentleman!" Hem, hem—"If I am a gentleman!" "Dares" me too!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Yes. I have now thrown myſelf upon your protection: and if you deliver me to my enemies—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What enemies? What buſineſs have you with enemies?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis they have buſineſs with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: [to them without.] I am coming. The door ſhall be opened.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: [follows and lays hold of him.] Oh, for heaven's ſake, have pity on me—they are mercileſs creditors—I ſhall be d •• gged to a priſon. Do not deliver me up—I am unfortunate—I am overwhelmed with misfortune—have compaſſion on me! (She falls on her knees.)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (in great agitation) Don't kneel to me!—I don't mean you to kneel to me!—What makes you think of kneeling to me?—I muſt do my duty. (He unlocks the door.

div.stage: Enter Nabſon—Miſs Dorrillon ſteals behind the book-caſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What did you want, Sir?

sp.speaker: Nabſon.
sp.p: lady, that I have juſt this minute made my priſoner; but ſhe ran from me, and • ocked herſelf in here.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: [with ſurpriſe.] A •• eſted a • ady!

sp.speaker: Nabſon.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and if • ou mean to deny her being here, I muſt make bold to ſearch the room.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Let me look at your credent ••• s—(takes the writ)—"Elizabeth Dorrillon for ſix hundred pounds." Pray ſir, is it cuſtomary to have female names on pieces of paper of this denomination?

sp.speaker: Nabſon.
sp.p: Oh, yes, ſir, very cuſtomary. There are as many ladies who will run into tradeſmen's books, as there are gentlemen; and when one goes to take the ladies, they are a thouſand times more ſlippery to catch than the men.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Abominable▪—Well ſir, your preſent priſoner ſhall not ſlip through your hands, if I can prevent it. I ſcorn to defend a worth • eſs woman, as much as I ſhould glory in preſerving a good one and I give myſelf joy in being the inſtrument of your executing juſtice—[He goes and • ads Miſs Dorrillon from the place where ſhe was concealed—ſhe caſts down her head]—What! do you droop? Do you tremble? You, who at the ball to-night would have danced lightly, though your poor creditor had been periſhing with want! You who never aſked yourſelf if your extravagance might not ſend an induſtrious father of a family to priſon, can you feel on the proſpect of going thither yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: For what cauſe am I the object of your perpetual perſecution?

sp.speaker: Nabſon.
sp.p: Lor • ! Madam, the gentleman means to bail you after all: I can ſee it by his looks.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How, raſcal, dare you ſuppoſe, or imagine, or hint, ſuch a thing? [going up to him in anger.]

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: That's right, beat him out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No, Madam, he ſhall not go out of the houſe without taking you along with him. Puniſhment may effect in your diſpoſition what indulgence has no hope of producing.—There's your priſoner [handing her over to him]—and you may take my word, that ſhe will not be releaſed by me, or by any one: and it will be only adding to a debt ſhe can never pay, to take her to any place previous to a priſon. (with the emotion of reſentment, yet deep ſorrow.)

sp.speaker: Nabſon.
sp.p: Is that true, my lady?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor▪
sp.p: (after a pauſe) Very true. I have but one friend—but one relation in the world—and he is far away.

sp.speaker: Nabſon.
sp.p: More's the pity.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No, ſir, no—no pity at all—for if fewer • ine ladies had friends, we ſhould have fewer examples of profligacy. (She walks to the door, then turns to Sir William.)

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Sir William
sp.p:
(looking after her.) And perhaps I could forgive you. But I muſt not. No, this is juſtice—this is doing
my duty—this is ſtrength of mind—this is fortitude—fortitude—fortitude. (He walks proudly acroſs the ••• n, then ſtops, takes out his handkerchief, throws his head into it, and is going off.)

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary—a man following at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred, Mr. Mandred. (He turns.) Sir—Mr. Mandred—Sir—(in a ſupp •• cating tone) I preſume—I preſume, ſir—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What, Madam? what?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: I came, ſir, to requeſt a favour of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: So it ſhould ſeem, b • that novel deportment.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: If you would for once conſi ••• with lenity, frailty incidental to a woman who lives in the gay world—the

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: How much ſhe is led away by the temptation of fine cloaths, fine coaches, and fine things.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Come to the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: You are rich, we all know, though you endeavour to diſguiſe the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I can't ſtay to hear you, if you don't proceed.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: My requeſt is—ſave from the dreadful horrors of a jail, a woman who has no friend near her—a woman who may have inadvertent • y offended you, but who never—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: it is in vain for you to plead on her account—ſhe knows my ſentiments upon her conduct—ſhe knows the opinion I have formed of her—and you cannot prevail on me to change it.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Do you ſuppoſe I come to plead fo • Miſs Dor.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: No, I am pleading for myſelf. I am unfortunately involved in ſimilar circumſtances—I have a ſimilar debt to the ſelf-ſame tradeſman, and we are both at preſent in the ſelf-ſame predicament.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And upon what pretence did you ſuppoſe I would be indulgent to you, more than to her?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Becauſe you have always treated me with leſs ſeverity; and becauſe 〈◊〉 overheard o • juſt now ſay, you "ſhould glory in delivering from difficulty a good woman."

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And ſo I ſhould

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: How unlike the world!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
No—whatever the diſcontented may pleaſe to ſay, the world is affectionate, is generous, to the good; more eſpecially to the good of the female ſex; for it is only an exception
to a general rule, when a good woman is in pecuniary diſtreſs.

div.stage: Enter Lord Priory, humming a tune, but with a very ſerious face: he pulls out his watch with evident marks of anxiety—coughs—rubs his forehead—and gives various other marks of diſcontent and agitation.—Lady Mary obſerves him with attention, then ſidles up to him.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: By the good humour you appear in, my lord, I venture to mention to you my diſtreſſes. 〈◊〉 know the virtues of lady Priory makes my fai • ings conſpicuous; but then conſider the different modes to which we have been habituated—ſhe excluded from temptation—.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: No—ſhe ſhuns temptation. Has ſhe not in this very houſe been compelled to make exertions? Has ſhe not detected and expoſed both Mr. Mandred and Mr. Bron.?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Bronzely! Bronzely! How! (Aſide. Another rival?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: He has not done with him yet, I believe; for to tell the truth, he is now with her at my houſe in Parkſtreet. He taxed me with being jealous of my wife—To prove in what contempt I held the accuſation, I left them together, and bid him make love to her.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Is that poſſible.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I can't ſay I would have done ſo raſh an action, had I been married to ſome women—to you, for inſtance—but I have not a doubt of Lady Priory's ſafety: her mind, I know, is ſecure, and I have ſervants in the houſe to protect her from perſona • outrage. The only fear is, leſt he ſhould have received one; for 'tis now near two hours (looking at his watch) ſince I came away, and I have neither ſeen nor heard any thing of either of them!—But to your lad • ſhip • s concerns▪

sp.speaker: Lady Mary▪
sp.p: I am at this inſtant, my lord, in the power of an implacable creditor; and without a friend who will give bond for a certain ſum, 〈◊〉 muſt—I b • uſh to name it—be taken to a priſon

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I am not at all ſurpriſed at the circumſtance, Madam: but it amazes me that you ſhould apply to me for deliverance. You have a brother in town; why not ſend to him?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: He was my friend the very laſt time a diſtreſs of this kind befel me. (Weeps.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Aſk Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: He was my friend the time before.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely, then.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: And Bronzely the time before that.

div.stage: Enter Oliver.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Ah, Oliver! I am glad to ſee you, my good fellow. Ha! what have you done with Mr. Bronzely?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Nay, my lord, that I can't tell. I can't tell what he has done with himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: How long has he been gone from my houſe?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: He is not gone yet as I know of; for none of the ſervants let him out.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Not gone! and you can't tell where he is!

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: No, that we can't: we have looked in every room for him, and can't find him any where.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Not find him! (recollecting himſelf) Ho! ho! I thought how it would be—I thought he'd have ſome trick played him. Where's your lady?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: That I can't tell neither. We have looked in every room, and can't find her.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: 'Tis as ſure as I am alive. I and the butler, two footmen, and all the maids, have been looking in parlours, chambers, and garrets, every crick and corner, and no where can we find either Mr. Bronzely or my lady; but, wherever they are, there's no doubt but they are together. Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No doubt at all, Mr. Oliver.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Together! together! and not in my houſe! You tell a falſehood I'll go myſelf and find them.

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: You muſt look ſharp, then.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: How came you to miſs them?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: I chanced to go into the next room, to ſee if there was a proper • ire to get it well aired; I knew I had taken Mr. Bronzely to my Lady in the inner room, and I had heard them both laughing not a quarter of an hour before; but now, a • l on a ſudden, there was neither laughing nor talking, nor any noiſe at all—every thing was ſo quiet, you might have heard a pin drop.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory
sp.p: (anxiouſly.) Well

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: And ſo I thought to myſelf, thought I, I'll ſit down here; for my ad •• will be ringing ſoon: however, there was no ringing for a whole half hour; and ſo then I thought I would e'en rap at the door; but nobody called "Come in." So then I went in of my own accord; and there I found—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: Nobody! not a ſoul to be ſeen!

sp.speaker: Lord, Priory
sp.p: (affecting indifference.) Oh! ſhe has been playing Bronzely ſome trick! She has been hiding him; and in ſome miſerable place!

sp.speaker: Oliver.
sp.p: But why need ſhe hide herſelf along with him?

div.stage: Enter Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Mr.Norberry.
sp.p: My dear friend, my dear lord Priory, let me ſpeak with you alone.—I come upon buſineſs that—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: You look pale! What is your buſineſs? Tell it me at once.

sp.speaker: Mr.Norberry.
sp.p: It is of ſo delicate a nature—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I know my wife is with Mr. Bronzely—I left them together. I know he is a licentious man; but I know ſhe is an innocent woman.—Now, what have you to tell me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Norberry.
sp.p: What I have juſt learnt from one of your ſervants. About a quarter of an hour after you left them, they ſtole ſoftly out at the back of your houſe, ran to a poſtchaiſe and four that was in waiting, and drove off together full ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Gone! eloped! run away from me! left me! left the tendereſt, kindeſt, moſt indulgent huſband, that ever woman had!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: That we can all witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I was too fond of her—my affection ruined her—women are ungrateful—I did not exert a huſband's authority—I was not ſtrict enough—I humoured and ſpoiled her!—Bleſs me! what a thick miſt is come over my eyes!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: No, my Lord, it is clearing away.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Lead me to my room. (He is led off by Mr. Nor.exhauſted with grief and anger.)—Oliver looks after Lord Priory, then takes out his handkerchief, and follows him off crying.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh, how I enjoy this diſtreſs▪ Ha, ha, ha!
sp.stage: The officer who has attended her during the ſcene, and kept at the farther part of the ſtage, now comes forward, and bows to her. She ſtarts on ſeeing him—takes out her handkerchief, and goes crying off at the oppoſite ſide.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I. An Apartment at Bronzely's.
div.stage: Enter Houſekeeper and Footman.

sp.speaker: Hous.
sp.p:
Dinner enough for twelve, and only two to ſit
down to it! Come home without one preparation—not a bed aired, or the furniture uncovered.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: This is not the firſt time he has done ſo.

sp.speaker: Hous.
sp.p: No; but it's always thus when a woman's in the caſe. Well, I do ſay that my own ſex are—

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Huſh! here they are. Run away.

div.stage: Enter Lady Priory and Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Only twelve miles from London?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: No more, be aſſured.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: And you avow that I did not come hither by the commands of my huſband, but was deceived into that belief by you.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Still it was by his commands your ſervant introduced me to you; and, upon an errand, which I feared to deliver till I arrived at a houſe of my own.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: What is the errand?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: To tell you that—I love you.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Do you aſſert, lord Priory ſent you to me for this?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I aſſert, that, in triumph at your betraying to him our private appointment, he gave me leave to have a ſecond trial. If, then, you have ever harboured one wiſh to revenge, and forſake a churliſh ungrateful partner, never return to him more—but remain with me.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: And what ſhall I have gained by the exchange, when you become churliſh, when you become ungrateful? My children's ſhame! the worlds contempt! and yours! (Smiling) Come, come; you are but jeſting, Mr. Bronzely! You would not affront my little ſhare of common ſenſe by making the ſerious offer of ſo bad a bargain. Come own the jeſt, and take me home immediately.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Is it impoſſible for me to excite your tenderneſs?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Utterly impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I will then rouſe your terror.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Even that I defy.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Lady Priory, you are in a lonely houſe of mine, where I 〈◊〉 maſter, and all the ſervants ſlaves to my will.
sp.stage: (Lady Priory calmly takes out her knitting, draws a chair, and ſits down to knit a pair of • lockings.)

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: (aſide.) This compoſure is worſe than reproach—a woman who meant to yield would be outrageous.—(Goes to ſpeak to her, then turns away.) By heaven ſhe looks ſo reſpectable in that employment, I am afraid to inſult her. (After a ſtruggle with himſelf.) Ah! don't you fear me?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: No—for your fears will protect me—I have no occaſion for my own.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: What have I to fear?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Your fear to lounge no more at routs, at ba • ls, at operas, in Bond-ſtreet; no more to dance in circles, chat in ſ • de boxes, or roar at taverns: for you have obſerved enough upon the events of life to know—that an atrocious offence like violence to a woman, never eſcapes condign puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Oh! for once, let your mind be feminine as your perſon—hear the vows—
sp.stage: (he ſeizes her hand—ſhe riſes—he ſtarts back)

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Ah! did not I tell you, you were afraid? 'Tis you who are afraid of me. (He looks abaſhed.) Come, you are aſhamed, too—I ſee you are, and I pardon you.—In requital, ſuffer me to return home immediately. (He ſhakes his head.]—How! are not you aſhamed of yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: I was not this moment—But now you mention it, I think I am.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Repent your fo • ly then, and take me home. (haſtily).

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Can you wiſh to go back to the man who has made this trial of your fidelity, and not reſent his conduct?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Moſt aſſuredly I wiſh to return. But if you deliver me ſafe, perfectly ſafe from farther inſult, it will be impoſſible for me not to ſhew reſentment to Lord Priory.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Why only in that caſe?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Becauſe, only in that caſe, you will make an impreſſion on m • heart—and I will reſent his having expoſed me to ſuch a temptation.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Oh! I'll take you home directly—this moment.—I make an impreſſion on your heart. William!—(calling)—I'll take you home directly. Here John, Thomas, William—(calling) But, upon my life, it would be a hard taſk—I cannot do it—I am afraid—I am afraid I cannot—Beſides, what are we to ſay when we go back?—No matter what, ſo you will but think kindly of me. (Enter Servant.)—Order the horſes to be put to the chaiſe; I am going back to London immediately. Quick! quick! Bid the man not be a moment, for fear I ſhould change my mind.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The chaiſe is ready now, Sir; for the poſt-boy was going back without unharneſſing his horſes.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p:
Then tell him he muſt perform his journey in
half an hour—If he is a moment longer, my reſolution will ſtop on the road. (Exit Ser.) I feel my good deſigns ſtealing away a • read • —now they are fl •• ing rapidly. (Taking Lady Priory's hand)—Pleaſe to look another way—I ſhall certainly recant if I ſee you. (Going)—And now ſhould I have the reſolution to take you ſtraight to your huſband, you will have made a more contemptible figure of me by this laſt trick, than by any one you have played me.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: (Without) Tell the poſt-boy he need not wait—I have changed my mind—I ſha • n't go to London to-night.

div.head: SCENE II. A Room in a Priſon.
div.stage: Enter Miſs Dorril on and Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: You ought to have known it was in vain to ſend for me. Have not I repeatedly declared, that, till I heard from your father, you ſhould receive nothing more from me than a bare ſubſiſtence?—I promiſe to allow you thus much, even in this miſerable place: but do not indulge a hope that I can releaſe you from it. (She weeps—he goes to the door—then returns.) I forgot to mention, that Mr. Mandred goes on board to-morrow for India; and, little as you may think of his ſenſibility, he ſeems concerned at the thought of quitting England without juſt bidding you farewel. He came with me hither—ſhall I ſend him up?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Oh! no: for heaven's ſake! Deliver me from his aſperity, as you would ſave me from diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis for the laſt time—you had better ſee him. You may be ſorry, perhaps, you did not, when he is gone.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No, no; I ſha'nt be ſorry.—Go and excuſe me—Go, and prevent his coming. I cannot ſee him.—(Exit Mr. Norberry)—This would be aggravation of puniſhment, to ſhut me in a priſon, and 〈◊〉 not ſhelter me from the inſults of the world!

div.stage: Enter Sir William.—(She ſtarts)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: —I know you have deſired not to be troubled with my viſit; and I come with all humility—I do not come, be aſſured, to reproach you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Unexpected mercy!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: No; though I have watched your courſe with anger, yet I do not behold its end, with triumph.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: It is not to your honour that you think it neceſſary to give this ſtatement of your mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: May be—but I never boaſted of perfection, though I can boaſt of grief that I am ſo far beneath it. I can boaſt too, that, though I frequently give offence to others. I could never part with any one for ever (as I now ſhall with you), without endeavouring to make ſome atonement.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You acknowledge, then, your cruelty to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I acknowledge I have taken upon me to adviſe, beyond the liberty allowed by cuſtom to one who has no apparent intereſt or authority.—But, not to repeat what has paſſed, I come with the approbation of your friend Mr. Norberry, to make a propoſal to you for the future.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: What propoſal?—What is it? [eagerly.]

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Mr. Norberry will not give either his money or his word to releaſe you—But as I am rich—have loſt my only child—and wiſh to do ſome good with my fortune, I will inſtantly lay down the money of which you are in want, upon certain conditions.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Do I hear right? Is it poſſible I can find a friend in you?—a friend to relieve me from the depth of miſery! Oh Mr. Mandred!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Before you return thanks, hear the conditions on which I make the offer.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Any conditions—What you pleaſe!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You muſt promiſe, never, never to return to your former follies and extr •• agancies. (She looks down.) Do you heſitate? Do you refuſe?—Won't you promiſe?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I would, willingly—but for one reaſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: The fear, I ſhould not keep my word.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You will, if your fear be real.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: It is real—It is even ſo great, that I have no hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: You refuſe my offer then, and diſmiſs me? (riſes.)

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: (riſing alſo.) With much reluctance.—But I cannot, indeed I cannot make a promiſe, unleſs I were to feel my heart wholly ſubdued; and my mind entirely convinced that 〈◊〉 ſhould never break it—Sir, I am moſt ſincerely obliged to you for the good which I am ſure you deſigned me; but do not tempt me with the propoſal again—do not place me in a ſituation, that might add to all my other afflictions, the remorſe of having deceived you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p:
(after a pauſe.) Well, I will diſpenſe with
this condition—but there is another I muſt ſubſtitute in its ſtead.—Reſolve to paſs the remainder of your life, ſome few enſuing years at leaſt, in the country. (She ſtarts.) Do you ſtart at that?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: I do not love the country. I am always miſerable while I am from London. Beſides, there are no follies or extravagancies in the country.—Dear Sir, this is giving me up the firſt condition, and then forcing me to keep it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: There, Madam, (taking out his pocket-book) I ſcorn to hold out hopes, and then deſtroy them. There is a thouſand pounds free of all conditions (ſhe takes it)—extricate yourſelf from this ſituation, and be your own miſtreſs to return to it when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Oh, my benefactor, bid me farewell at parting—do not leave me in anger.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: How! will you dictate terms to me, while you reject a • l mine?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Then only ſuffer me to expreſs my gratitude—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Then hear me on another ſubject: a ſubject of much importance—indeed it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You are going to India immediately—It is poſſible that there, or at ſome place you will ſtop at on your way, you may meet with my father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You have heard that I have expected him home for ſome time paſt, and that I ſtill live in hopes.—

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Well!—(anxiouſly)

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: If you ſhould ſee him, and ſhould be in his company—don't mention me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Not mention you?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: At leaſt, not my indiſcretions—Oh! I ſhould die, if I thought he would ever know of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Do you think he would not diſcover them himſelf, ſhould he ever ſee you?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: But he would not diſcover them all at once—I ſhould be on my guard when he firſt came—My ill habits would ſteal on him progreſſively, and not be half ſo ſhocking, as if you were to vociferate them all in a breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: To put you out of apprehenſion at once—your father is not coming home—nor will he ever return to his own country.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: You ſeem to ſpeak from certain knowledge—Oh! heavens! is he not living?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Yes, living—but under ſevere affliction—fortune has changed, and all his hopes are blaſted.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor
sp.p: "Fortune has changed!"—In povert • ?—my father in poverty?—(wee • ing)—Oh▪ Sir▪ excuſe, what may perhaps appear an ill comp • iment to your bounty; but to me, the greateſt reverence I can pay to it.—You are going to that part of the world where he is; take this precious gift back, ſearch out my father and let him be the object of your beneficence.—[Forces it into his hand.]—I ſhall be happy in this priſon, indeed 〈◊〉 ſhall, ſo 〈◊〉 can but give a momentary relief to my dear, dear father.—[Sir William takes out his handkerchief]—You weep:—This preſent, perhaps, would be but poor alleviation of his ſufferings—perhaps he is in ſickneſs; or a priſoner: Oh! if he is releaſe me inſtantly, and take me with you to the place of his confinement.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: What! quit the joys of London?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: On ſuch an errand, I would quit them all without a ſigh—And here I make a ſolemn promiſe to you—(kneeling.)

sp.speaker: Sir Wm▪
sp.p: Hold, you may wiſh to break it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Never—exact what vow you will on this occaſion, 〈◊〉 will make, and keep it.—[Enter Mr. Norberry.—She riſes.]—Oh! Mr Norberry, he has been telling me ſuch things of my father—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Has he? Then kneel again—call him by that name—and implore him not to diſown you for his child.

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Good heaven!—I dare not—I dare not do as you require. [She faints on Norberry.]

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (going to her) My daughter!—My child!—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: At thoſe names ſhe revives.—(She raiſes her 〈◊〉 , but expreſſes great agitation.)—Come, let us quit this wretched place—ſhe will be better then. My carriage is at the door. You will follow us.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: Follow you!—Yes—and I perceive that, in ſpite of philoſophy, juſtice, or reſolution, I could follow you all the world over.

div.head: SCENE III. Another Room in the Priſon.
div.stage: Lady Mary diſcovered ſitting in a dejected poſture, at a miſerable table.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p:
Provoking • not an anſwer to one of my
pathetic letters!—no • a creature to come and condole with me!—Oh that 〈◊〉 could but regain my liberty before my diſgrace is announced in the public prints—I could then boldly contradict every paragraph that aſſerted it—by We have authority to ſay, no ſuch event ever took p • ace.

div.stage: Enter a Man belonging to the priſon.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: One Sir George Eve • yn is here, Madam; he will not name your name, becauſe it ſha'n't be made public; but he deſires you will permit him to come and ſpeak a few words to you, provided • ou are the young lady from Groſvenor-ſtreet, with whom he has the pleaſure of being acquainted.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am the young lady from Groſvenor-ſtreet—my compliments to Sir George, I am that lady; intimately acquainted with him; and entreat he will wa • k up. (Exit the Man.) This is a moſt fortunate incident in my tragedy! Sir George no doubt takes me for Miſs Dorrillon; yet I am ſure he is too much the man of gallantry and good breeding to • eave me in this p • ace, although he viſits me by miſtake.
sp.stage: Sir George Evelyn (ſpeaking as he enters)

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Madam, you are free—the doors of the priſon are open—my word is paſſed for the—[He ſtops—looks around—expreſſes ſurpriſe and confuſion.]

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: (curtſying very low) Sir George, I am under the moſt infinite obligation!—Words are too poor to convey the ſenſe I have of this act of friendſhip—but 〈◊〉 truſt my gratitude will for ever—

sp.speaker: Sir George
sp.p: (confuſe • .) Madam—really—I ought to apologiſe for the libert • I have taken.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: No liberty at all, Sir George—at leaſt no apology is neceſſary—I inſiſt on hearing no excuſes. A virtuous action requires no preface, no prologue, no ceremony—and ſurely, if one action be more noble and generous than another, it muſt be that one, where an act of benevolence is conferred, and the object, an object of tota • indifference to the libera • benefactor—Generous man, good evening—Call me a coach.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Stay, Madam—I beg leave to ſay—

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: —Not a word—I won't hear a word—my thanks ſhall drown whatever you have to ſay.

div.stage: Enter the former Man.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, did not you tell me, you had a very young lady under your care?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſo I had—but ſhe, it ſeems, has juſt been releaſed, and is gone away with the gentleman who paid the debt

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Do you mean Miſs Dorrillon?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I mean the other lady from Groſvenor-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Who can have releaſed her?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Some friend of mine, I dare ſay, by miſtake—Well, if it is ſo, ſhe is extremely welcome to the good fortune which was deſigned for me. For my part, I could not ſubmit to an obligation from every one—ſcarcely from any one—and from no one with ſo little regret as I ſubmit to it from Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Diſtraction! the firſt diſappointment is nothing to this ſecond! to the reflection that Miſs Dorrillon has been ſet at liberty by any man on earth except myſelf.

div.head: SCENE IV. An Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.
div.stage: Enter Lord Priory

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: What a ſituation is mine! I cannot bear ſolitude, and am aſhamed to ſee company! I cannot bear to think on the ungrateful woman, and yet I can think of nothing elſe! • t was her conduct which I imagined had alone charmed me; but I perceive her power over my heart, though that conduct is changed!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Norberry, Sir William, and Miſs Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: My dear Lord Priory, exert • our ſpirits to receive and congratulate a friend of mine. Sir William Dorrillon (preſenting him) father to this young woman, whoſe failings he has endeavoured to correct under the borrowed name of Mandred.

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And with that fictitious name, I hope to diſburthen myſelf of the imputation of having ever offered an affront to my lord Priory. (He takes Lord Priory aſide, and they talk together.)

div.stage: Enter Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Is it poſſible what 〈◊〉 have heard is true? was it Mr. Mandred who has reſtored Miſs Dorrillon to the protection of Mr. Norberry?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: (coming forward.) No, Sir George, I have now taken her under my own protection.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: By what tit • e, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: A very tender one—don't be alarmed—I am her father.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: Sir Wm. Dorrillon? (They talk apart.)

div.stage: Enter Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Has there been any intelligence of my Lady Priory yet? (ſees Miſs Dorrillon) My dear Dorrillon, a lover of yours has done the civileſt thing by me!—As I live, here he is. How do you do, Sir George? I ſuppoſe you have all heard the news of Bronzely running away with—

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Huſh!—Lord Priory is here.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Oh, he knows it—and it is not improper to remind him of it—it will teach him humility.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory▪
sp.p: I am humble, Lady Mary, and own I have had a better opinion of your ſex than I ought to have had.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: You mean, of your management of us; of your inſtructions, reſtrictions, and corrections.

div.stage: Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Lady Priory and Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: What of them?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: They are here.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I ſaid ſhe'd preſerve her fidelity! Did not I always ſay ſo? Have I wavered once? Did I not always tell you all that ſhe was only making game of Bronzely? Did I not tell you all ſo?

div.stage: Enter Bronzely and Lady Priory.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Then, indeed, my Lord, you ſaid truly; for I return the arranteſt blockhead—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I always ſaid you would! But how is it? Where have you been? What occaſion for a poſt-chaiſe? Inſtantly explain, or I ſhall forfeit that dignity of a huſband, to which, in thoſe degenerate times, I have almoſt an excluſive right.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: To rei • ſtate you • my Lord, in thoſe honours, I accompany Lady Priory; and beg public pardon for the opinion I once publicly profeſſed, of your want of influence over her affections.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Do you hear? Do you all hear? Lady Mary, do you hear?

Taking advantage of your permiſſion to call on her, 〈◊〉 ſtratagem I induced her to quit your houſe, •• ſt reſtraint might there act as my enemy. But your authority, your prerogative your honour attached to her under my roof. She has held thoſe rights ſacred, and compelled even me to revere them.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Do you all hear? I was ſure it would turn out ſo!

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: This is the firſt time I ever knew the gallant's word taken for a woman's honour.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I will take her own word—the tongue which for eleven years has never in the ſlighteſt inſtance deceived me, I wil • believe upon all occaſions. My dear wife, boldly pronounce before this company that you return to me with the ſame affection and reſpect, and the ſelf-ſame contempt for this man—(to Bron.)—you ever had.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: She makes no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Huſh! Huſh! She is going to ſpeak.—(Another pauſe)—Why, why don't you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Becauſe I am at a loſs what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Hear, hear, hear—do you all hear?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Can you be at a loſs to declare you hate Mr. Bronzely?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I do not hate him.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: I was ſure it would turn out ſo.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Can you be at a loſs to ſay you love me?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: She is at a loſs.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: How! Don't you fear me?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: She ſpeaks pla • ly to that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: You know I love truth—ſpeak plainly to all their curioſity requires.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Since you command it then, my Lord—I confeſs that Mr. Bronzeley's conduct towards me has cauſed a kind of ſentiment in my heart—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Hah! what?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: You muſt believe her—"ſhe has told you truth for eleven years."

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: A ſenſation which—

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Stop—any truth but this I could have borne—Reflect on what you are ſaying—Conſider what you are doing—Are theſe your primitive manners?

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: I ſhould have continued thoſe manners, had I known none but primitive men. But to preſerve ancient auſterity, while, by my huſband's conſent. I am aſſailed by modern gallantry, would be the taſk of a ſto •• , and not of hi • female ſlave.

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Do you hear? Do you all hear? My Lord, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: I do—I do—and though the ſound diſtracts me, I cannot doubt her word.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: It gives me exceſſive joy to hear you ſay ſo, becauſe you will not then doubt me when I add—that gratitude, for his reſtoring me ſo ſoon to you is the only ſentiment he has inſpired.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: Then my management of a wife is right after all!

sp.speaker: Mr. Norberry.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely, as your preſent behaviour has in great meaſure atoned for your former actions, I will introduce to your acquaintance my friend Sir William Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Bronzely.
sp.p: Mandred, Sir William Dorrillon!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: And conſidering, Sir, that upon one or two occaſions I have been honoured with your confidence—you will not be ſurpriſed, if the firſt command I lay upon my daughter, is—to take refuge from your purſuits, in the protection of Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: And may I hope, Maria?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: No—I will inſtantly put an end to all your hopes.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ George.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Wm.
sp.p: By raiſing you to the ſummit of your wiſhes. Alarmed at my ſeverity, ſhe has owned her readineſs to become the ſubject of a milder government.

sp.speaker: Sir George.
sp.p: She ſhall never repin • at the election ſhe has made.

sp.speaker: Lord Priory.
sp.p: But, Sir George, if you are a prudent man, you will fix your eyes on my little domeſtic ſtate, and guard againſt a rebellion.

sp.speaker: Lady Priory.
sp.p: Not the rigour of its laws has ever induced me to wiſh them aboliſhed.

sp.speaker: Bronzely
sp.p: Dear Lady, you have made me think with reverence on the matrimonial compact: and I demand of you, Lady Mary—if, in conſequence of former overtures, I ſhould eſtabliſh a • egal authority over you, and become your chief magiſtrate—would you ſubmit to the ſame controul to which Lady Priory ſubmits?

sp.speaker: Lady Mary.
sp.p: Any controul, rather than have no chief magiſtrate at all.

sp.speaker: Sir George
sp.p: And what do you ſay to this?

sp.speaker: Miſs Dor.
sp.p: Simply one ſentence—A maid of the preſent day ſhall become a wife like thoſe—of former times.

div.head: ADDRESS, WRITTEN BY MR. TAYLOR; SPOKEN BY MISS WALLIS.

l.hi: WELL, female critics, what's the ſentence, ſay—
Can you with kindneſs treat this ſaucy play,
That gives to ancient dames the wreath of praiſe
And boldly cenſures thoſe of modern days?
Bring us good huſbands firſt, and, on my life,
For every one we'll ſhew as good a wife.
Whate'er the errors in the nuptial ſtate,
Man ſets th' example to his paſſive mate:
While all the virtues the proud ſex can claim
From female influence • caught the gen'rous flame.
Nay, though our gallant rulers of the main
'Tis Woman triumphs—that inſpiring charm
With tenfold vigour nerves the hero's arm:
For King and Country though they nobly bleed,
The ſmile of Beauty is their deareſt m • ed.
And valiant tars ſhould ſtill be Beauty's care
Since 'its "the brave alone deſerve the fair."

div.head: WIVES AS THEY WERE, AND MAIDS AS THEY ARE: A COMEDY,
div.p: Performed at the London and Dublin Theatres with univerſal applauſe—and at Greenwich-ſtreet, New-York.
